original_text: Since different breeds of dogs have different proportions, weight alone cannot allow you to determine an appropriately-sized cage. [substeps] Measure your dog at its widest, tallest, and longest points, then multiply those measurements together to determine your dog's size. Add 1-2 inches to those measurements to determine your dog's cage size. TIP: Remember to measure from the floor to the top of your dog's head and back, not just from head to tail. Here are the recommended cage sizes for different breeds. Because most dogs are prone to chewing, we recommend using a welded cage rather than a bolted one. This prevents your dog from chewing and escaping from the cage. TIP: Avoid wire cages with large mesh or wire diameters. These can cause your dog to cut or puncture its paws. We've found that plastic or poly-coated cages are easier to clean and more sanitary than wire or steel ones. TIP: If you're concerned about your dog being able to chew through the cage, opt for a poly-coated wire cage. Finally, we recommend that your cage have a top that your dog cannot remove. TIP: The top should be secure enough that your dog cannot chew or push it off. Pet cages come in a variety of colors and styles. However, make sure that you consider your dog's needs over your own aesthetic choices. If you're concerned that your dog will chew on its cage, opt for a cage with a plastic or poly-coated finish. We recommend cages with large doors that allow you to remove your dog easily. TIP: Some cages come with removable trays, which make cleaning a breeze. If you're housing multiple dogs or have a smaller dog, consider purchasing an enclosure with multiple cages. TIP: If you're housing multiple dogs, make sure that they are able to see each other. We recommend that you avoid cages with small openings. These can be dangerous for your dog, particularly if it is a puppy. TIP: Make sure that your cage is big enough to allow your dog to stand upright. In order to keep your dog comfortable, opt for a cage with a soft, padded mattress. For your convenience, consider purchasing a cage with wheels. TIP: If you're housing multiple dogs, make sure that the cage is big enough for you to comfortably fit your hand in order to pet them. TIP: Some cages come with built-in bowls, making feeding time more convenient.

"A brush is better for blending and for adding color," says Niko. [substeps] Choose a concealer that's one to two shades lighter than your foundation. "If you use a concealer that's too light, it'll look like you're wearing white paint," says Niko. [substeps] "Always blend the concealer onto your face, never pat it on," says Niko. "Patting can cause the product to settle into fine lines."

original_text: For example, if you lost your coat on the playground, you should check in the office's lost and found rather than addressing the issue in a letter to your principal. You can send a note like this to the office manager or other administrative staff, or you can hand it to a staff member directly. If you hand it to a staff member, make sure to include their name at the end of the letter, which helps the recipient know who they should address the response to. I'm writing to inform you that I lost my green coat on the playground yesterday. It was hanging from a hook on the fence when I left for lunch and was gone when I returned. I was wondering if you've seen it, or if someone turned it in to the lost and found. I would really appreciate it if you could check around. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to give me a call. original_text: [substeps] If you don't already have a therapist or psychologist, ask your doctor for a referral. You can also search online for therapists who treat your mental illness and use your health insurance. If you don't already have a therapist or psychologist, ask your doctor for a referral. You can also search online for therapists who treat your mental illness and use your health insurance. Educate yourself about your illness. Knowledge is power. You can find out about your illness by searching online or visiting your local library. The more you know about your illness, the more likely you are to overcome it. Accept your illness. The first step to overcoming any mental illness is to accept that you have it. This is not your fault. Nobody chooses to be mentally ill. It's not weakness or laziness. Nobody chooses to have diabetes or cancer, either. But you can choose to overcome your mental illness. Start to consider recovery. Recovery from mental illness is a long process. You should set realistic, small goals for yourself. Prioritize your treatment. Your mental illness is the most important thing in your life. You should schedule therapy appointments ahead of other commitments, and you should not make any other plans that interfere with your therapy appointments. Understand that treatment requires time and commitment. Treatment for mental illness is usually a long process. Most people go through several different treatments before they find the right one. Find a support group. Support groups provide a safe environment for people with similar mental illnesses to come together and talk about their feelings. Join a support group. This could be online, in person, or a combination. In a support group, you can ask others about their experience with therapy. Educate your family and friends. If your family and friends don't understand your illness, they will not be able to provide you with the support you need to get better. Be honest with your family and friends. This does not mean that you should be negative about yourself or your illness, but you should not be afraid to talk about it. The more you talk about your illness, the less shame you will feel. Encourage your family and friends to educate themselves. You can give them books or articles to read. Teach your family and friends what to do during a mental health crisis. You should teach them how to talk to you, what to say and what not to say. You should also teach them how to talk to you about getting treatment. You can give them sample scripts. Ask your family and friends to encourage you to get better. If you are having a bad day, tell them to say things like "I'm proud of you" or "I'm here for you." Try to stick to a schedule. A schedule will help you get back on track. You can create a schedule for your therapy appointments, medication schedule, and workschoolchores. Plan for triggers. Triggers are things that make you feel bad. For example, if a person who broke up with you calls you, this could be a trigger. If you have a trigger, you should try to avoid it. If you can't avoid it, you should plan a way to deal with the trigger. Avoid self-medication. Many people with mental illness turn to alcohol or drugs as a coping mechanism. This is not a good way to treat your illness. In fact, it will make it worse. Don't smoke. Smoking is bad for you. The chemicals in cigarettes will worsen your mental illness. If you are a smoker, you should consider quitting. Create a crisis plan. A crisis plan is a plan for what to do when you have a mental health crisis. You should give this to your therapist, family and friends. It should include contact information for your therapist and familyfriends. It should also include information about what you should do in case of a mental health crisis.
text: Here are some tips from the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) on how to overcome mental illness: If you already have a therapist or psychologist, ask them for a referral.

There are many reasons that sibling rivalry begins. Some of the reasons are:. Researchers believe that there are many other factors that influence sibling rivalry, such as birth order, personality, and genetics. Birth order can influence the way that children get along with each other. Children who are born first, and are therefore the oldest, tend to be natural leaders. They can be bossy and manipulative. They may enjoy being in control of their younger siblings. Younger siblings often want to break away from the older siblings' control and have some power of their own. Sibling rivalry may be worse if children are born close together in age. Younger children may feel that they are always playing catch up to the older sibling. Younger children may be envious of the older sibling's abilities and accomplishments. Gender is another factor that can influence sibling rivalry. Many parents complain that their children bicker more often when they are of the same gender. Sibling Rivalry and Favoritism in the Home Children of the same gender may bicker over the same toys, clothing, or other items. They may compete over who is the better athlete, or who has the better grades. They may fight over who is the "favorite" child. Sibling rivalry can be a normal part of growing up. It is a natural part of children learning to compete and share. It is up to parents to teach their children to work out their problems with each other. They must also set firm rules that everyone must follow. Sometimes sibling rivalry can become severe. This can be due to a variety of reasons. Children may become excessively jealous, and may have difficulty controlling their anger. Sometimes, children may begin to be physically aggressive toward each other. Sibling rivalry can also become severe when one child is abused. This may lead to severe sibling rivalry. Sibling rivalry can also be influenced by parents' behavior. If one child is favored over the other, the favored child may begin to feel superior to the other child. The child who is not favored may feel inferior. Children who feel inferior may start to fight with the favored child. Children who are not favored may start to misbehave, because they feel that they are being ignored. This may lead to more severe sibling rivalry. It is important that parents try to treat all of their children fairly. They should spend time with each child individually, and as a family. Parents should have firm rules that apply to everyone in the family. They should also praise and reward each child for good behavior. Parents should encourage their children to work out their problems, and not to use physical aggression. It is important that parents be consistent in enforcing the rules. If you allow one child to do something one day, you should allow the other children to do the same thing. If you do not allow one child to do something one day, you should not allow the other children to do it either. It is also important that parents give their children enough attention. Children who feel ignored may act out and misbehave. Parents can help their children cope with sibling rivalry by setting good examples. If you are married or living with a partner, you should have a good relationship with each other. Children who see their parents or guardians get along well, may be more likely to get along with each other. There are several steps that parents can take to help prevent or reduce sibling rivalry. Poverty, single parent homes, and crowded living conditions all contribute to sibling rivalry. Parents should try to spend time alone with each child. A documentary on the Yellowknife Dene entitled: "The Land is Our Life" was shown to the students. Following the viewing, the students were led through a presentation on traditional Dene culture. The presentation was given by several students from the Yellowknife Dene community. As a culmination to their studies, the grade 12 class travelled to the Dene community to take part in a number of traditional activities. The day was divided into two main sections, with a morning devoted to traditional fishing, hunting and trapping activities, and an afternoon spent at the Dene Cultural Centre. The morning was spent at the Cameron River, where the students had the opportunity to try their hand at ice fishing, net fishing, trapping and dry fish preparation. "This was such a great experience. I've never seen the Dene fishing before, so this was very interesting," said Heather Kryzanowsky. "It's really cold here," said Rebecca Smith, who, along with her classmates, took a break to warm up by the fire. At the Dene Cultural Centre, the students were welcomed by Elders. "The students are very lucky to have this opportunity," said Elder Adam Moosetail. "This is a very special experience for the students, especially now that we have the Cultural Centre," he added. The students were treated to a Dene lunch of caribou, moose and bannock. After lunch, the students went to the centre's museum, where they were treated to a presentation by Dene elders. The students then went to the centre's art gallery, where they had the opportunity to see some of the artwork done by local Dene artists. The students were very impressed with the artwork. "I can't believe how talented these artists are," said Nicole St. Jean. "I think these artists are amazing," added Heather Kryzanowsky. This has been an incredible experience for these students, many of whom have never been to the Dene community before. It is hoped that this trip will foster greater understanding and respect between the students and the Dene community. "This was a great experience," said Heather Kryzanowsky. "I've never been to the Dene community before, but I'll definitely be back." "This was a great day for the students," said teacher Linda Sutherland. "It's so important that the students learn about the Dene, and we're very grateful to the Dene community for allowing us to come here."
text: Students from the Charles S. Winchester School in Yellowknife have been learning about the traditional Dene lifestyle during a trip to the Yellowknife Dene community.

original_text: You can by specially formulated chromatography strips for superior results, but for simple chromatography you can make your own. Cut a coffee filter into straight strips about 1 inch (2.5 cm) wide and 4 inches (10 cm) long. Place your mixture on a strip of filter paper and wait for it to wick up the paper. The components of your mixture will travel through the filter at different rates based on their molecular weight. As they move up the filter, you should begin to see a separation of your mixture. You may need to experiment with different solvents. You can use water, isopropyl alcohol, or a mixture of the two. If you use water, it will be easier to see the separation of your mixture. If you use isopropyl alcohol, you will see fewer molecules move through the filter, but they will travel faster. Our example uses water and two colors of ink. The colored ink contains three different dyes: magenta, cyan, and yellow. Magenta is the most polar, followed by cyan and then yellow. As the water moves through the filter paper, the magenta will move through first, followed by the cyan, and finally the yellow.

I think my skin was looking a little dull and I wanted to brighten it up. I wanted my skin to look polished and glowing for the big day. I applied this with a circular motion, going in small circles to cover all of my face. I rinsed it off with cool water and dried it with a towel. I used a small dollop of the Yes To Tomatoes Detoxifying Charcoal Facial Scrub for my chest and back. I used my hands and massaged this in, then rinsed it off with cool water. I love using this scrub because it smells SO good. My skin feels super clean and soft afterwards. The granules are really gentle so I didn't feel like my skin was being aggressively exfoliated. I have been using the Proactiv 3 Step System for almost three weeks and my skin has been looking the best it has in a while. When I was younger, I used Proactiv for years and I loved it. I didn't want to use anything else! I started using it again because I wanted to try and get rid of the acne scars I have on my face. I was super impressed with the 3 Step System. I used the Skin Smoothing Exfoliator which contains microbeads to slough off dead skin, while the salicylic acid gets rid of dirt and oil. I applied this primer because it's the only primer I have that is both white and thick. My face tends to be pretty oily so I like to use a primer that is thick and has a white base to it. I applied it in a thin layer all over my face. I used the buffing brush to apply the liquid foundation to my face. I used small circular motions and blended it into my skin. I used a small amount of the concealer to cover up any dark spots and redness on my face. I used the same buffing brush to blend it in. I used a small amount of the highlighter to highlight my cheekbones, brow bones, and the inner corner of my eyes. I applied the bronzer to my cheeks to give my face some color. I applied the blush to my cheeks to add a little color and shine. I applied the eyeliner all along the top of my eyelid, from the inner corner all the way out to the middle. I applied it with short strokes. I applied the eyeshadow with the eyeshadow brush and blended it with the same brush. I put the darker color on the outer corner of my eyelid and the lighter color on the inner corner of my eyelid. I applied the mascara to the top and bottom lashes. I used a small amount of lipstick to give my lips some color. I finished off the look with the lip balm. I think I need a new primer, and maybe a new foundation. I love how my eyes turned out, but I'm not a big fan of the rest of my look. I have been using the same makeup for quite some time. I know there is better products out there. Maybe I'll try a new primer or foundation next time.

original_text: From there, try to narrow things down to explore a variety of careers based around a broad interest. Together, write down a list of interests. Then, do some online research about careers that incorporate those interests. For example, if your teen is interested in medicine, consider careers like pharmacy tech, medical lab technologist, or genetic counselor. If your teen loves helping people, think about careers like nursing, physical therapy, or elder care. If your teen is interested in marketing, consider advertising, social media, or public relations. Take time to sit down with your teen and discuss possible careers. Ask what careers interest your teen. Why do they interest your teen? What skills are necessary for a career in a particular field? How much education is necessary? What is the average starting salary? You can also encourage your teen to take career assessments. Many of these can be found online. Many colleges and universities have similar career assessments available for students to take. Encourage your teen to apply for jobs or internships in a variety of fields. In addition to building valuable skills, a job or internship helps teens explore career options. It also helps them figure out what type of work environment they want to work in. If your teen wants to work in a certain industry but cannot find a job or internship, encourage them to shadow a professional. They can learn about the day-to-day tasks, as well as the pros and cons of the career. Talk to friends, neighbors, and other parents to see if they know of anyone who works in the industry your teen wants to explore. If you don't know anyone, ask your teen's teachers and school counselors. Volunteering is another way your teen can explore different careers. They can choose to volunteer in a variety of fields. They can even choose to volunteer in a different field than their desired career. Volunteering is a great way to develop skills that will benefit your teen's career. It is also a great way to meet others who are working in different fields. You never know who your teen will meet. Colleges and universities provide a variety of opportunities for students to explore careers. Many provide mentorship programs for students to explore career opportunities. They also provide internship and volunteer opportunities. Your teen's school may also provide career-related programs or courses. If they don't, the school counselor can be a great resource for career exploration. Encourage your teen to talk to their college advisor or the career center to explore career opportunities. Exploring careers may seem overwhelming at first, but with your support, your teen can find a career they will love. By following these tips, you can help your teen on the path to finding their dream career.
text: Here are some tips to help you find a career that fits your teen's interests: Start by asking your teen what they want to do when they grow up.

As he walks through the fields, he points out various plant species that have been carefully nurtured and protected to ensure that the native species are not overtaken by nonnative plants. He walks to an overlook from which a broad expanse of woodland can be seen. "We've already planted thousands of trees on this site," he says, "and there's more to come. I don't know if there's anywhere else in the world where an institution of higher education has made this kind of investment in its natural environment." The woodland he describes is part of the Piedmont Physiographic Province, one of the eight provinces comprising the state's geographic regions. The word "Piedmont" is French for "foot of the mountain," and it accurately describes the physical characteristics of the land that stretches from the Blue Ridge Mountains to the Atlantic Coastal Plain. "We're standing at the edge of the Piedmont Plateau, looking down toward the Coastal Plain," says Jim Flueck, an associate professor of biology at UGA and one of the experts who helped shape the plans for the university's new campus. "The Piedmont is an area of gently rolling hills and relatively low elevations, while the Blue Ridge Mountains to the north and the Atlantic Coastal Plain to the south are more dramatic in their topography. "In the state of Georgia, the Piedmont forms a transition area between the two," he continues. "It's part of the Piedmont physiographic province, and it's a very diverse environment with a wide variety of plant and animal species. It's an environment that's attractive to human beings, and it's also the environment that the University of Georgia has occupied since 1801." What is the Piedmont? As the name implies, the Piedmont region stretches from the mountains to the coast, and it is home to Georgia's capital city, Atlanta, which sits on the Piedmont Plateau. The plateau is divided into three major sections: the Blue Ridge Province to the north, the Piedmont Upland Province in the center and the Fall Line Lowland Province in the south. The highest elevation in the Piedmont is on Brasstown Bald, the state's highest mountain, which reaches an elevation of 4,784 feet. The lowest elevation is found in the Fall Line Lowlands. The Piedmont is sometimes called the Piedmont Plain because it is characterized by gently rolling hills and low elevations. The Piedmont Upland Province, which is located in the center of the Piedmont region, is generally more rugged than the other two provinces, and it is home to the Pine Mountain, the longest mountain ridge in Georgia. original_text: There are glass, pvc, melamine, abs, and vision cages to choose from. [substeps] A traditional vivarium has wooden sides with a sliding glass frontage. A pvc vivarium has no wooden sides, but is instead made of pvc (plastic) on all sides. The glass frontage is fixed. The plastic side panels allow for easy access to your pet. This is a more convenient option for pet care, but you might feel it looks a bit ugly. A melamine vivarium is similar to a traditional vivarium in that it has wooden sides, but the frontage is covered in melamine to make the vivarium look more modern and to provide a smooth surface. An abs vivarium is made of abs (acrylonitrile butadiene styrene), which is a hard plastic. The advantage of abs vivariums is that they are less likely to warp than wooden vivariums, so they provide a more stable environment. An abs vivarium also has a smooth exterior. A vision vivarium is made from clear plastic, which allows you to see your pet more easily and allows your pet to see its surroundings more clearly. One of the most important factors to consider is the size of the vivarium. You need to make sure you have the right size vivarium for your pet. Vivariums come in many sizes. You can choose from a small, medium, large, or extra large vivarium. You will also need to consider the space available in your home, especially in terms of where you are planning to place the vivarium. In addition to the vivarium itself, you will also need to purchase other essential items. These include a substrate, a hygrometer, a thermometer, an under tank heater, a water bowl, a nest box, food bowls, and any equipment you need to clean the vivarium. When you have decided on the type of vivarium and its size, you will need to choose the accessories you need. The accessories include a substrate, a hygrometer, a thermometer, an under tank heater, a water bowl, a nest box, food bowls, and any equipment you need to clean the vivarium. In general, the herbs used in natural medicine are prepared through drying or tincturing. Drying the herbs will allow them to last for years, while tincturing (usually in alcohol or glycerin) will allow the medicinal elements to be more readily absorbed into the bloodstream. You can combine the two techniques for the best of both worlds. Choose your herbs. The following is a list of the most common herbs used in natural medicine, their common ailments and their prescribed remedies. Aloe Vera - This herb has been used since Biblical times. It contains compounds which aid in the healing of wounds, burns, and skin irritations, and it also works as a laxative and can be used to treat many stomach disorders. Black Walnut - The husk of this fruit is used to treat ringworm and skin disorders, and the bark of the tree can be used to treat syphilis. Burdock - This is commonly used in the treatment of skin conditions. It can also be used to treat arthritis, high blood pressure and diabetes. Calendula - The flower of this plant is used to treat minor cuts and burns, skin ulcers, and is a popular remedy for diaper rash. Catnip - Catnip is good for treating anxiety, insomnia, depression, and it can also help with digestive issues such as constipation and gas. Chamomile - This flower is used to treat insomnia, menstrual cramps, and stomach disorders. It is a popular natural remedy for children. Cinnamon - Cinnamon is most commonly used for treating diabetes, but it has also been shown to be effective in treating fatigue and exhaustion, arthritis, and digestive problems. Dandelion - Dandelion root can be used to treat kidney problems, bile flow issues, and it can help to regulate blood pressure. original_text: Decide what your approach or angle on the story is going to be. [substeps] For example, you can start with a simple plot like, your main character has to deal with a problem, then use it as a springboard to tie it into a bigger theme. Or you can start with a theme and build a plot around that. Check out the plot that you have devised so far, and identify the biggest plot holes. What are the missing steps or elements that are vital to the story? [substeps] For example, if your character has to break into a prison, the logical question would be, how is he going to do that? If he does not have a plan, then the plot will be weak. Brainstorm ideas for the missing elements, and integrate them into the plot. Go through the plot again and identify the second-largest plot hole, and repeat the process for step 3. Repeat step 4 for all the smaller plot holes that you have identified. Some plot holes will not be so easy to fill. For example, maybe your character has to kill a villain, but you do not want to break the rules. Then you can add something else that will make the villain's death plausible. For example, you can have your character find a sword that can kill the villain, or he can have a gun that can blow him up, but he refuses to use it because he is a pacifist. Then, he can find a way to make the villain kill himself. Do this until all the plot holes have been filled. Ask a friend to read your plot and tell you if there are any plot holes that you might have missed. If you really have no idea where to start or if you want to be inspired, consider reading or watching some of the following stories. Write your plot down in a word document. Ideally, your plot should be no longer than a page, so you do not have to add too many details and descriptions. A plot is the sequence of events that form the story of a movie or book. The plot is made up of the following: setting, characters, conflict, rising action, climax, and falling action.

original_text: Maybe they will, maybe they won't, but if your expectations don't match reality, you're likely to end up disappointed. [substeps] Trying to change your partner will result in a lot of disappointment, especially if your partner doesn't feel the same way about themselves as you do. Whatever your reasons for wanting to be in a relationship with someone, it should be because you feel good about yourself when you're with them, not because you feel bad about yourself when you're not with them. I can't tell you how many times I've seen women and men who are otherwise wonderful, competent and caring people, make themselves absolutely miserable with unrealistic expectations of a relationship. Expectations about the relationship - are they realistic? If you're in a relationship that isn't working for you, you're not alone. Are you and your partner having some problems? I can help you work through them. It's my belief that when we're dating or in a relationship, we expect certain things from the other person. We expect that they'll be thoughtful, that they'll be considerate, that they'll do things for us and with us. And if we're lucky, and the relationship is working for us, they will. And when they do, we're happy. But if we're not lucky, and things aren't working for us, then we tend to believe that there's something wrong with our partner. We're either trying to convince them to do the things that we want them to do, or we're trying to change them in some way. I'm not saying that it's not possible to have a relationship that's working for you, and be with a partner who's willing to do things for you. I'm saying that if that's what you're looking for, you're likely to be disappointed. I'm saying that there are some things that we can't change about another person. I'm also saying that when we're dating or in a relationship, it's not always about what the other person is willing to do for us. It's also about what we're willing to do for ourselves. Is there something you'd like to be doing in your life, something you'd like to be different about yourself, something that's not happening? If there is, think about whether or not you're expecting your partner to do that for you. Think about whether or not that expectation is realistic. I know it's difficult to hear that we can't always change another person. I know it's difficult to hear that we can't always expect another person to do things for us. But it's true. We can't. What we can do is focus on what we can change. What we can do is focus on what we can do for ourselves. We can focus on what we can do differently, in order to have the kind of relationship we want. And then, we can start to do it.

original_text: To prepare the tea, stir a half teaspoon (2.5 g) of the powder into a cup of hot water. Alternatively, you can combine the same amount of powder with honey and water to make a drink. For a soothing beverage, try adding milk. The tea is also available in a variety of forms, including liquid extracts and capsules. Most people can drink ginger tea without any problems. However, it can cause certain side effects, such as heartburn, nausea, and mouth irritation. If you have a health condition, talk to your doctor before trying ginger tea. Ginger is one of the world's healthiest foods. In fact, it's been used as a natural remedy for thousands of years. Its active compounds have been shown to relieve nausea, reduce inflammation, and protect against diseases. Here are 10 proven health benefits of ginger. If you have digestive issues, ginger may be especially helpful. It's been shown to speed up emptying of the stomach, especially when there are delays in the movement of food from the stomach to the small intestine (1, 2). In one study, consuming 1.2 grams of ginger powder before a meal reduced indigestion and stomach discomfort in people with indigestion (3). Ginger has also been shown to help relieve nausea and vomiting. In a review of 12 studies, ginger was found to be more effective than a placebo in preventing nausea caused by morning sickness or chemotherapy (4). Another study found that ginger may relieve nausea caused by motion sickness. In this study, 12 to 18-year-olds who took 1 gram of ginger powder had less nausea and vomiting than those who took a placebo (5). Summary Ginger may help relieve indigestion, nausea, and vomiting. Inflammation is one of the leading drivers of many common Western diseases. Interestingly, ginger contains compounds that may help reduce inflammation. In a test-tube study, ginger extract reduced the production of nitric oxide, which is believed to play a role in inflammation. In addition, animal research has shown that ginger may help reduce joint inflammation in those with arthritis (6, 7). In one study in 247 people with osteoarthritis, those who took ginger extract had less pain and required less pain medication than those who took a placebo. The extract was also shown to reduce the use of pain medications (8). Summary Ginger contains compounds that may help reduce inflammation. Research has shown that it may help relieve pain and reduce the need for pain medication in people with osteoarthritis. Ginger is a common ingredient in many dishes, and research has shown that it may help relieve nausea caused by seasickness, morning sickness, and chemotherapy. It may also help reduce the symptoms of indigestion and improve the movement of food through the intestines. Lastly, ginger contains compounds that may help reduce inflammation, which can contribute to disease.

original_text: Look at your accumulated clothes and possessions, your home, friends, family, job, the food in your cupboards, everything. Maybe there isn't much for you to look at now, but be thankful for what you do have. Think about how you have a bed, shoes, clothes, a way to get to work or school, friends, family, food, and a roof over your head. These things are gifts from God, and the Bible says that everything we have is a gift from Him. The Bible says that Jesus didn't have a home. He was so poor that he had to borrow a donkey to ride on, and his mother had to wrap him in rags when he was born. But he was happy and content because he knew that his Father in heaven cared for him. When he asked God to feed the five thousand, God provided loaves and fishes from the generosity of a little boy. But you say, "I don't know God." Or, "I've never seen God." You may not have a close relationship with God, but you have been given the same gifts that Jesus had: the air to breathe, the earth to walk on, the sun to warm you and the rain to water the crops to feed you. These are gifts from God. He sent Jesus to live as a man and to die on the cross to pay the price for your sins so that you can have peace and joy in your life now, and so that you can go to heaven to be with God after you die. God loves you, and He wants you to love Him back. You can't buy His love. He gave it to you freely because He loves you. All you have to do is to accept it.

[substeps] Increase your retirement savings. If you have an employer-matched 401 (k), make sure to contribute as much as you can to that plan to receive the matching funds. (You can also consider an IRA if you have maxed out your 401 (k).) And be sure to check in with your investments at least once a year. [substeps] Start collecting Social Security. You can start collecting Social Security at age 62, but if you do, your benefit will be 25 percent less than it would be if you waited until your full retirement age (66 or 67, depending on when you were born). The longer you wait, the bigger your check will be. If you wait until age 70, you'll get 32 percent more than you would have at 66. You can find your full retirement age here. [substeps] Evaluate your spending. "Make sure you're not overspending, and that you're setting aside money for unexpected expenses, " says Frankie Lymon, financial planner and owner of Lymon Financial Services in Washington, D.C. [substeps] Decide what you want to do in retirement. " If you don't have a plan, you won't know how much money you'll need, " says Devin Carroll, financial planner and founder of Social Security Intelligence in Portland, Oregon. [substeps] Consider hobbies, travel, volunteering, and how much money you'll need for your preferred lifestyle. [substeps] Consider your healthcare needs. Make sure you have your Medicare Part B application in order, and consider a Medigap policy or Medicare Advantage plan to supplement Medicare coverage. [substeps] Run a retirement-income projection to understand how much money you'll need. You can use your own spreadsheet, or an online calculator like T. Rowe Price's Retirement Income Calculator. [substeps] Determine if you're on track. According to Fidelity's 2018 analysis, couples retiring this year will need 280,000 for healthcare expenses alone. To get a sense of your progress, try a retirement calculator like this one from Wells Fargo. [substeps] Check your credit score, and try to improve it if you're close to retirement. "The lower your credit score, the higher your credit card interest rates and other financing costs, " says Rick Jarvis, credit card expert and vice president of consumer education at the credit card comparison site CardRatings.com. [substeps] Get rid of any high-interest debt. " If you don't want to be a slave to debt in retirement, it's important to eliminate your credit card balances before you stop working, " Jarvis says. [substeps] Consider downsizing. " If you're planning to move, downsizing can free up equity that can be used for other things, " says certified financial planner Mark LaSpisa, founder of Vermillion Financial Advisors in South Barrington, Illinois. [substeps] Check out reverse mortgages. " If you're considering moving to a smaller home, this could be a source of funds to do so, " LaSpisa says. [substeps] Make sure you're receiving all the benefits you're entitled to. " Have you applied for all of the benefits for which you are eligible ? For example, some people don't know they can claim Social Security based on a former spouse's earnings, " Lymon says. [substeps] Consider whether you want to work in retirement. " Some people are happy working until they die, but others want to have more freedom to travel or spend time with family, " LaSpisa says. original_text: Pull the long central threads (the pistils and stamens) out and discard them. [title] Rinse and soak the flowers for 10 minutes. Drain and spread them on a tea towel to dry. Cut off the top and root ends, then trim a small slice off the bottom. With a very sharp knife, make a cross incision on the bottom and carefully peel away the rind, leaving the white flesh. Cut the orange into thin slices and put them in a small saucepan with the sugar and 250ml water. Bring to the boil, then turn down the heat and simmer for 10 minutes or until the liquid is syrupy and reduced by half. Turn off the heat, leave to cool and then strain the syrup into a small bowl, discarding the solids. [title] Put the orange syrup in the fridge to chill. Whip the cream until just soft peaks form, then fold in the chilled orange syrup and refrigerate until required. Fold the cream into the fromage blanc, then add the Grand Marnier and some of the orange blossom water, if using. Check the seasoning. Put the fromage blanc mixture into a piping bag fitted with a star nozzle and pipe into the centre of each orange segment. Sprinkle with the pistachios and serve.
text: To make the fromage blanc, put the orange blossom water in a small saucepan and bring to the boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for 10 minutes, or until the water has reduced by half.

original_text: Your sixth grader will learn how to: [substeps] Multiply and divide fractions. Understand ratios and rates, and solve word problems relating to ratios and rates. Determine the probability of an event occurring. The lessons, activities, and test items in this workbook are aligned to the Common Core State Standards (CCSS) for mathematics. Grade 6 covers the standards for Number and Operations in Base Ten (NO-NBT), Number and Operations - Fractions (NOF), Ratios and Proportional Relationships (RP), The Number System (NS), Expressions and Equations (EE), and Statistics and Probability (SP). The lessons for each of these clusters are divided into three sections: K-2, 3-5, and 6-8. Each section offers a different level of complexity to meet the expectations of learners at different grade levels. The K-2 section gives an introduction to the topic, and the 3-5 and 6-8 sections show students more complex ways of applying the topic to solve problems. The first three CCSS clusters - NO-NBT, NOF, and RP - are integrated throughout the book, and the other three - NS, EE, and SP - are grouped at the end. The first six CCSS clusters are aligned with 6.NS.A, 6.NS.B, 6.NS.C, 6.NS.D, 6.NS.E, 6.NS.F, 6.EE.A, 6.EE.B, 6.EE.C, 6.EE.D, 6.EE.E, 6.EE.F, 6.RP.A, 6.RP.B, 6.RP.C, 6.SP.A, 6.SP.B, and 6.SP.C. At the end of each lesson, the Quiz showcases the CCSS for that lesson and prepares students for the CCSS test items. Each lesson is followed by a test that covers the objectives for the lesson. The lesson test items are designed to assess students' understanding of the content. The lesson tests can be used to prepare students for the CCSS test items. The CCSS test items at the end of each section are designed to assess students' mastery of the grade-level standards. To gain a deeper understanding of the lesson content, have students work in pairs or groups to solve the problems. Use the test items and the Quiz to evaluate students' mastery of the CCSS for mathematics.
text: This workbook covers the standards for Number and Operations in Base Ten, Number and Operation - Fractions, Ratios and Proportional Relationships (RP), and The Number System (NS).

original_text: is performing gymnastics on bars as his coach watches him. She sees a little boy with energy and life and says, "Oh, he's like a little monkey." Later, as he's doing a routine on the pommel horse, she says, "He's really stiff and trying too hard. He needs to relax and just have fun." There's nothing wrong with trying hard, it's just that I think sometimes we get so focused on the "doing" that we forget the "being." I know that's a little bit of a vague comment, but if you look at my life, I can see where it's true. As I've become more and more involved in my church, I have been going at the "work" (pun intended) so hard, I've forgotten the "being." Sometimes I wonder if I'm just trying to prove something to somebody. If I'm being completely honest, I know it's because I feel like I need to prove something to God, that I'm worthy of my calling to work with the youth. It's as though I'm saying, "See God, I'm doing it, I'm doing my best." The truth is that I'm not perfect and I never will be. I will never be good enough for God or for the people I work with. But that's okay. I don't have to be. I will never be good enough for God, but God is good enough for me. I will never be good enough for people, but God is good enough for them. I will never be good enough for anyone, but God is good enough for everyone. Today, I'm just going to be. I'm going to relax and just have fun because I'm loved and accepted by God, no matter what I do or don't do. And I'm going to remember that I'm not perfect, but I'm perfectly loved by my God. I'm so glad that God loves me with an unfailing love and that He is always with me, no matter what I'm doing. I don't know about you, but that gives me great comfort and joy. What are you going to do with your life? What are you going to do with your day? Will you do it with God? I'm so glad God is with me. It is such a comfort.
text: I've been thinking a lot lately about how we get so focused on the "doing" (pun intended) that we forget the "being" in our lives.

original_text: , he inserts a needle into her left eyebrow, followed by the jewelry. "It's very easy to put in and take out." She says. A few weeks after her appointment, she removed the earring and healed completely. "I didn't get any infections, no fevers, nothing." she said. "It was painless and easy." Her doctor is one of 414 providers in the United States who are specially trained to do body modifications, a field of medicine that is gaining traction with patients. "Pain is the number one complaint in the United States," said Brian Decker, who trains doctors in micro-cannula techniques. "So it's our mission to decrease pain, increase safety and provide a beautiful outcome." His students are mostly doctors in the emergency room, oncology or plastic surgery. "They're looking to have a greater impact on their patients," he said. "They're looking to be more useful, to have another tool in their toolbox." Decker uses a technique called micro-cannula, which inserts an ultra-fine needle into a patient's skin. The device doesn't go through the skin, but allows the doctor to place jewelry without penetrating the skin. Decker said micro-cannula can be used on any part of the body, from a earlobe to the tongue. "The great thing about micro-cannula is that there's no scar tissue," he said. "So you can do it again and again. It doesn't matter how many times you've done it in the past." In addition to cosmetic body modification, Decker said the technique could be used on patients who have difficulty taking medication, like children or the elderly. Instead of swallowing a pill, the patient could take a pill in a capsule and put it directly into the body. "It could be a game changer, especially for people who have to take medication," he said. However, Decker said his students often get a negative reaction from the medical community. "I think a lot of it is 'not in my backyard, he said. "Most physicians will tell you they've seen things in their practices that they don't want to see, they don't want to know about and they don't want to treat. And body modification is one of those things." Even though many doctors are uncomfortable with body modification, Decker said there is still a demand for the service. "The medical community doesn't want to provide the service, but there's a huge demand for it," he said. "And that's where we come in."
